story: `` You think it 's this place that kills you ? No . It has n't been lethal for over 11000 years . No , that 's not it . It 's us that do . '' <newline> <newline> A rock hit the temple of his head and first a pain and then a dull , pulsing feeling accompanied him to the void . <newline> <newline> The man left standing cursed to himself . <newline> <newline> `` God damn idiot . God damn machine . Shit . Shit . SHIT . It was only a few days on that planet . Two god damm days . '' <newline> <newline> A tear formed and fell . It was only a couple of months more of collecting weakly radioactive material but it seemed like an eternity .

prompt: 12.000 years in the future . Civilizations fell and rose . Technology back on renaissance level . Mysterious area where no one can survive . Turns out to be Chernobyl .
story:
In the year 10222, the world was a vastly different place. The once-mighty empires of old had crumbled, leaving behind only ruins and the whispers of a bygone era. The people of this new world had risen from the ashes, rebuilding their civilization on a foundation of primitive yet resilient technology. The Renaissance had returned, with artisans and inventors hewing wood, weaving cloth, and crafting metalwork with precision and artistry.

But amidst this resurgence of human ingenuity, there existed a place that was shrouded in mystery and terror. A region so cursed, so poisoned, that not even the hardiest of adventurers dared to venture near. They called it the "Devil's Exclusion Zone."

Rumors of this forsaken place had been passed down through generations, a cautionary tale told around campfires and in hushed whispers. Some said it was a place of dark magic, where the very fabric of reality was twisted and distorted. Others claimed it was a site of ancient power, where the earth itself had been scarred and corrupted.

Ava, a young and fearless explorer, had always been drawn to the unknown. She had spent years studying the ancient lore of the world, pouring over dusty tomes and listening to the tales of grizzled old travelers. And so, when she finally stumbled upon a map that hinted at the location of the Devil's Exclusion Zone, she knew she had to see it for herself.

Assembling a small team of trusted companions, Ava set out on the perilous journey. They traveled through treacherous mountains and dark forests, following the winding path that led to the heart of the Exclusion Zone. And when they finally arrived, they were met with a sight that took their breath away.

The landscape was barren and twisted, a maze of radioactive waste and toxic sludge. The air was thick with the acrid smell of decay, and the ground seemed to writhe and twist beneath their feet. Ava's team hesitated, unsure of what to do next.

But Ava was undeterred. She led the way, her eyes fixed on the horizon as she navigated the treacherous terrain. And then, suddenly, they saw it: the ruins of a great city, its buildings twisted and deformed by the power of the radiation.

As they explored the ruins, Ava's team stumbled upon a series of cryptic symbols etched into the walls. They seemed to be some sort of warning, a message from a long-lost civilization that had perished in this very place.

And then, Ava saw it: a small plaque, half-buried in the dust. It read: "Chernobyl, 1986. A disaster of unimaginable proportions. A warning to all who would follow."

Ava's team looked at each other in stunned silence. They had heard the stories, of course, but they had never imagined that the truth was so close, so personal. The Devil's Exclusion Zone was not a place of dark magic or ancient power, but a reminder of the devastating consequences of human hubris and greed.

As they made their way back to civilization, Ava couldn't help but feel a sense of awe and reverence for the people who had come before. They had built a world of wonder and discovery, but they had also created a world of destruction and despair. And it was up to the people of the future to learn from their mistakes, to build a better world, and to never forget the lessons of the past.

prompt: A time traveller interviews major historical figures at three points in their lives : Their 16th birthday , the day after they made their most important decision , and the day before they die .
story: `` What do you want to be when you grow up ? '' Robert McCallister did n't care for the question any more than I did , but such mundane questions were necessary to sell the disguise . He was n't looking at me , he was looking through me , demonstrating his complete indifference to my presence . Of all the great kings and ruthless tyrants I 've interviewed throughout the ages , I had never felt as nervous , as intimidated , as I felt now . By a boy none-the-less ! Today I was playing school counselor for the boy that would invent the time machine . I did n't even attempt to stop him as he walked out of the office . Talking had never been one of my strong points , but this interview had crashed before it ever started . I may have failed this time , but I could n't stop my smile if I tried . Next week I 'd be there watching as he announced to the world his machine was a success ! What a day ! <newline> <newline> Today is the day ! The man who is to be my final subject , my grand finale ! Not a single open seat in the stadium , and yet there was not a whisper to be heard . How fortunate I am to have gained backstage access , and even more so , his promise of some one-on-one time . I had heard the speech a thousand times before , everyone from my timeline had . This was the day that changed the world . I had no need to be there , I had a job to do and I had to be ready . The applause resonating through the wall was enough to tell me his speech had come to a close , and my second chance was fast approaching . My tie was straight . My thoughts were clear . Pen was ready . I was prepared . But he was gone . Next week I had one more chance , one more opportunity . Next week would be this man 's last moments . I was scared . <newline> <newline> Time is a funny thing , you can see into the future or you can explore the past , but no matter how hard you tried , fate would remain fate . I 've known this day would come since I started my travels , yet I still feel so ill-prepared . It is the day the great Robert McCallister would die . A man who had seen eternity in his short 34 years , taken out by a drunk driver . here comes the truck now ! I had so much to ask , but could n't think of a thing to say . I knew it was coming . I was never good with dialogue , but I thought this time I was prepared ! There was n't much time , I had enough for a single question . I have to ask something ! `` How can a man interview his-damned-self ? ! ''

prompt: A time traveller interviews major historical figures at three points in their lives : Their 16th birthday , the day after they made their most important decision , and the day before they die .
story:
The time traveller stood before the grand clock tower, its intricate mechanisms ticking away the seconds. With a deep breath, he stepped into the swirling vortex, leaving behind the familiar world of the 21st century. His destination: the lives of the most influential figures in history.

First, he materialized in the midst of a bustling Renaissance fair, where a young Leonardo da Vinci stood, his 16th birthday celebration in full swing. The time traveller approached the artist, his eyes shining with curiosity.

"Maestro, I am but a humble visitor from a far-off land," the time traveller said, bowing low. "I wish to learn from you, to understand the spark that ignited your creative fire."

Da Vinci's eyes sparkled as he gazed at the time traveller. "Ah, the spark of curiosity, the flame of passion. It is a fire that burns within us all, waiting to be fanned into a blaze of greatness."

The time traveller listened intently as Da Vinci spoke of his early fascination with art and science, of the countless hours he spent sketching and experimenting. As they spoke, the time traveller noticed a small, leather-bound book lying open on a nearby table. Da Vinci's eyes followed his gaze, and a hint of a smile played on his lips.

"Ah, yes. My notebooks. The chronicles of my thoughts, my dreams, my fears. They hold the secrets of my creative process, the keys to unlocking the mysteries of the universe."

The time traveller closed the book, his mind racing with the implications. He knew that he had only scratched the surface of Da Vinci's genius, but he was grateful for the glimpse into the young artist's mind.

Next, the time traveller found himself standing in the midst of a crowded courtroom, where a young Martin Luther stood, his 16th birthday just a day behind him. The time traveller approached Luther, his heart pounding with anticipation.

"Reverend Luther, I am but a humble seeker of truth," the time traveller said, his voice barely above a whisper. "I wish to understand the catalyst that set your soul ablaze with conviction."

Luther's eyes blazed with intensity as he gazed at the time traveller. "It was the day I read the Bible, the day I realized that the Church had strayed from the path of righteousness. I knew then that I had to speak out, to challenge the status quo, to stand up for what I believed in."

The time traveller listened, mesmerized, as Luther spoke of his journey, of the struggles and the triumphs, of the countless hours he spent pouring over scripture and debating with his peers. As they spoke, the time traveller noticed a small, leather-bound book lying open on a nearby table. Luther's eyes followed his gaze, and a hint of a smile played on his lips.

"Ah, yes. My Bible. The source of my strength, my inspiration, my conviction. It holds the words of the prophets, the wisdom of the ages, and the guidance of the divine."

The time traveller closed the book, his mind racing with the implications. He knew that he had only scratched the surface of Luther's conviction, but he was grateful for the glimpse into the young theologian's soul.

Finally, the time traveller found himself standing in a small, dimly lit room, where a frail, elderly Albert Einstein sat, his eyes cloudy with the weight of time. The time traveller approached the physicist, his heart heavy with sorrow.

"Professor Einstein, I am but a humble visitor from a far-off land," the time traveller said, his voice barely above a whisper. "I wish to understand the final chapter of your life's journey."

Einstein's eyes sparkled, despite the frailty of his body. "Ah, the final chapter. It is a time of reflection, of looking back on a life well-lived. I think of all that I have accomplished, all that I have learned, and all that I have loved."

The time traveller listened, entranced, as Einstein spoke of his life's work, of the countless hours he spent pondering the mysteries of the universe. As they spoke, the time traveller noticed a small, leather-bound book lying open on a nearby table. Einstein's eyes followed his gaze, and a hint of a smile played on his lips.

"Ah, yes. My notebooks. The chronicles of my thoughts, my dreams, my fears. They hold the secrets of my creative process, the keys to unlocking the mysteries of the universe."

The time traveller closed the book, his mind racing with the implications. He knew that he had only scratched the surface of Einstein's legacy, but he was grateful for the glimpse into the old physicist's soul.

As the time traveller prepared to leave, Einstein's eyes locked onto his. "Remember, my young friend, that the spark of curiosity, the flame of passion, and the keys to unlocking the mysteries of the universe are all within you. It is up to you to fan the flames, to pursue your dreams, and to leave your mark on the world."

The time traveller nodded, his heart filled with a sense of wonder and awe. He knew that he had been given a rare gift, a glimpse into the lives of three of history's greatest minds. As he stepped back into the swirling vortex, he knew that he would carry the lessons of Da Vinci, Luther, and Einstein with him for the rest of his life.

story: I 've been at this for years . <newline> <newline> People tell me the job must be stressful because it looks like it 's taking years off my life . <newline> <newline> I laugh . Sixty two and I feel ninety . <newline> <newline> I have nothing left to me . <newline> <newline> Except a gift . <newline> <newline> This girl is a drug addict . She is twenty three . She is dead . <newline> <newline> I stare down at her . <newline> <newline> I lay my hand on her forehead . <newline> <newline> I can feel the life ready to leave my body . prompt: A mortician has the ability to restore the body and soul of a deceased person at the cost of 1 year off of his/her lifespan . Tell of the events leading up to his/her death .
story:
Emmett had always been drawn to the world of the dead. As a young man, he had spent countless hours studying the intricacies of human anatomy, fascinated by the mysteries of life and death. After completing his apprenticeship, he had worked his way up to become a respected mortician, known for his attention to detail and compassionate care for the deceased.

But it wasn't until his 50th birthday, surrounded by friends and family, that Emmett discovered his extraordinary gift. A young woman, barely out of her teens, had been brought to his mortuary, her life slipping away with each passing moment. As he worked to prepare her body for burial, he felt an inexplicable surge of energy course through his veins. He closed his eyes, focused all his will, and whispered a single word: "Revive."

To his amazement, the woman's eyes flickered open, and she took a deep breath. She was alive, her soul restored to her body. Over the next few weeks, Emmett experimented with his newfound power, using it to revive several more individuals who had been pronounced dead. Each time, he felt a year of his own life slipping away, but he couldn't help but feel a sense of purpose and fulfillment.

As the years passed, Emmett's reputation grew, and people began to seek him out from all over the world. He became known as a miracle worker, a man who could bring the dead back to life. But with each revival, Emmett felt the weight of his years growing heavier. He knew that his time was limited, and that eventually, he would have to face the consequences of his gift.

Despite his concerns, Emmett couldn't bring himself to stop. He had seen the impact his power had on families, on communities, and on individuals. He had brought joy and hope to those who had thought all was lost. And so, he continued to revive, year after year, feeling the years slipping away from him.

But the cost was taking its toll. Emmett's health began to decline, his energy waning with each revival. His relationships suffered, as those around him grew concerned about his well-being. His family and friends tried to intervene, but Emmett couldn't resist the call of his gift.

One day, as he worked to revive a young mother, Emmett felt a sharp pain in his chest. He looked down to see a faint glow emanating from his heart, a sign that his time was running out. He knew that this would be his final revival, and that he would soon be leaving this world behind.

As the young mother took her first breath, Emmett felt a sense of peace wash over him. He had lived a full life, and had given his all to his gift. He smiled, knowing that he had made a difference, and that his legacy would live on through the countless lives he had revived.

With a final glance at the world around him, Emmett closed his eyes, and let go. His soul was free, and his body was at peace. The young mother wept, but Emmett's spirit was already gone, his journey at an end.

prompt: Everyone has superpowers , but the richer you are , the weaker your powers become .
story: `` This world is a horrible place . There 's no two ways about I 'm afraid . '' The beaten and weathered looking old man said to the young girl beside him on the bench , on a whim , who 'd struck up a conversation with him . <newline> <newline> `` Shall I tell you why ? Well I was going to anyway , so no need to fret young one . <newline> <newline> This world is such a horrible place because the most horrible , twisted and evil people thrive here . They thrive because their depravity and vile deeds rob them of their humanity and as a result , this world gives them back ... ... . *something else* in return . In the beginning we all have the power to stop them , otherwise this society would have ended long ago . However that does n't make living here any better . It never will . We all know what it 's like to sit here , in constant fear of the next big attack . We all fear when the next lunatic takes the stage , taking the screams of pain of others to be a sign to continue on . <newline> <newline> The police ? What can they do ? The more heroic their deeds , the less strength this world will provide to them . And the bigger a target they make themselves for the *powerful* . <newline> <newline> Then what of the heroes who are meant to fight these monsters when the police ca n't ? Well all of them do it because they lack something , some want attention , some want to protect and others ... . well you can understand everyone has their own reasons . <newline> <newline> The monetarily wealthy I hear you ask ? Heh . Those people usually want for nothing , leaving them without an ounce of this world 's power in their bodies . Undoubtedly there have been many who also abandoned their riches in pursuit of power , leaving the life of monetary wealth behind for the boundless power of this world which we 've all felt at one point or another . But achieving the power is n't like that . '' <newline> <newline> `` Most people do n't know this about the world but I 'll tell you a little secret , eh ? '' He paused looking expectantly at the girl seated beside him on the park bench who silently but meaningfully nodded . <newline> <newline> `` Good . Good . This world does not grant power so simply as that because there needs to be a deep hunger and thirst inside you . An emptiness of the soul . The more you secretly curse and despise this world , hate the transcendental force who gives this power and toys with our lives , the more power you receive . <newline> <newline> A feeling of anger or frustration . Of jealousy or envy . Of loss and regret . '' The man had spoke slowly but with intention up to this point , however once he mentioned loss and regret , his voice faltered . He coughed lightly which startled the girl somewhat but continued on . <newline> <newline> `` It would be better if you never had to rely on it . Using it eats away at your soul until there 's little left but a hollow shell and the thought which you founded your hatred on . I doubt your parents would never have seen this happen so it 's best not to tell them , but I can assure you that these cases happen . Anyway young one , it 's best you run along , no need to sit here listen to my ramblings on about the world '' He said , placing his hands on his knees while he heaved himself to his feet with a fake sounding grunt . <newline> <newline> `` Can I ask you one thing , sir ? '' The girl rushed out as this strange man made to leave . <newline> <newline> `` Anything , child '' The patience his voice carried seeming to be endless for this stranger . <newline> <newline> `` Why 'd you tell me all this ? '' She asked <newline> <newline> The man 's expression suddenly grew pained as he took a last look at the girl and his hand involuntarily reached for his pocket . <newline> <newline> `` You look just like her ... . '' Were the last words she heard before the man disappeared making such a noise the heavens themselves seemed to quake . <newline> <newline>

prompt: Everyone has superpowers , but the richer you are , the weaker your powers become .
story:
In the bustling metropolis of New Eden, the air was alive with the hum of superhuman abilities. Every person possessed a unique power, from the ability to fly to the power of telekinesis. However, there was a peculiar twist to this extraordinary world: the richer you were, the weaker your powers became.

Ava, a young and ambitious journalist, had always been fascinated by this phenomenon. She had grown up in a world where the wealthy elite possessed powers that were laughable, at best. The billionaire CEO of Omicron Incorporated could barely lift a pencil, while the mayor of New Eden could only make flowers bloom with a mere thought.

Ava's own power was the ability to see into the hearts of those around her. She could sense the deepest desires and darkest secrets of those she met. But despite her impressive power, Ava's family was struggling to make ends meet. Her father, a former scientist, had lost his job due to the company's downsizing, and her mother worked multiple part-time jobs just to put food on the table.

One day, Ava received a tip about a mysterious underground club where the wealthy elite would gather to flaunt their pathetic powers. Determined to expose the truth, Ava snuck into the club, her heart racing with excitement.

As she entered the lavish room, Ava was greeted by the sight of the city's elite, each one more pitiful than the last. There was Reginald, the CEO of Omicron, who could only make his tie change color with a mere thought. Next to him was the mayor, who could only make the lights flicker with a wave of his hand.

Ava's eyes scanned the room, searching for the most powerful person of all. And then, she saw him – the enigmatic billionaire, Marcus Blackwood. His power was said to be the most impressive of all, but Ava had heard rumors that it was nothing more than a myth.

As she approached Marcus, Ava felt a strange sensation wash over her. It was as if her power was being drained, her abilities weakening with each passing moment. She realized that Marcus's power was not just a myth, but a reality that was being fueled by his wealth and influence.

Ava's eyes locked onto Marcus, and she saw the truth. He was not a powerful being, but a puppet controlled by his own ego and desire for wealth. The more he had, the weaker his powers became, and the more he relied on others to do his bidding.

As Ava turned to leave, she felt a sense of hope. Maybe, just maybe, the truth would set her free. She knew that she had to expose Marcus and the rest of the wealthy elite, to show the world that their powers were nothing more than a facade.

With a newfound determination, Ava set out to take down the corrupt elite, using her power to guide her every step of the way. And as she walked out of the club, she felt her abilities growing stronger, her heart filled with a sense of justice and purpose.

In a world where everyone had superpowers, but the richer you were, the weaker your powers became, Ava had discovered a new truth – that true power came not from wealth or influence, but from the courage to stand up for what was right.

prompt: A costumed superhero sworn to uphold the law finds himself defending a corporation legally dumping hazardous waste into the local river from another superhero who fights to uphold his own moral code rather than the letter of the law , and is now attempting to destroy the offending facilities .
story: `` I 've respected you my entire life , I would n't be here if it was n't for you . But I can not stand for this ! '' Gold Foot shouted as he tensed his arms and started sending golden pulses down his body . The pulses then went down his right leg and once they hit the bottom of his foot his entire leg burst into a golden flame . <newline> <newline> Gray Man looked at him as they were both on the roof of police building . His gray and blue cape fluttered in the wind as the rain sputtered on his helmet . `` I do n't want to fight you , Gold Foot . Please just leave , the law wo n't allow you to do what you 're intending . '' <newline> <newline> `` But the law will allow a man like that to walk free ? ! '' <newline> <newline> Gray Man looked down towards the many officers gathered in front of the station watching what was taking place . Though they probably could n't hear them both because of the weather . `` Like the judge said , there was n't enough evidence- '' <newline> <newline> `` I was there , John ! '' Gold Foot interrupted `` I saw it all happen , are you calling me a liar ? '' <newline> <newline> Gray Man suddenly looked up at him , even with his eyes covered by a visor , you could hear the anger behind his voice . `` No , I 'm calling you coward . '' Gray Man said . The flames coming from Gold Foot 's leg suddenly flared . `` If you just revealed your identity and came to court like you were asked then that man would be behind bars this very second . '' <newline> <newline> Gold Foot started walking towards Gray Man . `` I 'll have to make things right then by getting a confession , even if I have to force it out of him . '' <newline> <newline> Gray Man disappeared and then reappeared right beside Gold Foot and attempted to hit him with his metal fist attack . Gold Foot raised his flaming leg and blocked the punch by folding his leg over his own torso . He then kicked his leg out , hitting Gray Man in the jaw . Gray Man teleported away as he fell back .

prompt: A costumed superhero sworn to uphold the law finds himself defending a corporation legally dumping hazardous waste into the local river from another superhero who fights to uphold his own moral code rather than the letter of the law , and is now attempting to destroy the offending facilities .
story:
The sun had barely risen over the city, casting a golden glow over the towering skyscrapers and bustling streets. But amidst the peaceful morning scene, a sense of unease settled over the river that flowed through the heart of the metropolis. The water, once a pristine and life-giving force, had become a toxic soup of chemicals and waste.

As the city's resident lawman, the superhero known as "The Guardian," stood watch over the river, he couldn't help but feel a sense of unease. His eyes scanned the horizon, searching for any sign of trouble. And then, he saw him - "The Vandal," a masked vigilante with a reputation for taking the law into his own hands.

The Vandal was a force of nature, driven by a fierce moral code that demanded justice, no matter the cost. He had been tracking the corporation responsible for the river's pollution, and now he had finally found them. The Guardian knew that if The Vandal succeeded in destroying the facilities, the consequences would be catastrophic.

The two superheroes faced off on the riverbank, their eyes locked in a fierce stare. The Guardian, clad in his iconic suit of blue and silver, stood tall and proud, his fists clenched at his sides. The Vandal, on the other hand, wore a twisted grin, his eyes blazing with a fierce intensity.

"You're a monster, Guardian," The Vandal spat, his voice dripping with venom. "You're just a pawn of the system, a tool of the corporations that care more about profits than people."

The Guardian sighed, his expression a mix of frustration and sadness. "That's not true, Vandal. I'm just trying to uphold the law, to protect the innocent. You're the one who's breaking the law, who's putting lives at risk."

The Vandal snorted. "The law is a joke, Guardian. It's a system designed to keep the powerful in power, to silence the voices of the marginalized. I'm not afraid to challenge it, to take a stand for what's right."

As the two superheroes continued to argue, the corporation's CEO appeared on the scene, flanked by his lawyers and security guards. "What's going on here?" he demanded, his voice dripping with entitlement.

The Guardian stepped forward, his voice firm and authoritative. "We're discussing the fact that your corporation is dumping hazardous waste into the river, putting the entire city at risk. We're going to take you down, and we're going to make you pay."

The Vandal, meanwhile, had already begun to dismantle the facility's security systems, his eyes gleaming with a fierce intensity. "You can't stop me, Guardian," he said, his voice dripping with triumph. "I'm going to make sure that this corporation pays for what they've done."

The Guardian knew that he had to act fast, to stop The Vandal before it was too late. He charged forward, his fists flying as he battled the masked vigilante. The two superheroes clashed in a flurry of punches and kicks, their movements lightning-fast as they fought for control of the facility.

In the end, it was The Guardian who emerged victorious, his superior training and skill proving too much for The Vandal. As the masked vigilante lay defeated on the ground, The Guardian stood over him, his chest heaving with exhaustion.

"I know you're fighting for what you believe in, Vandal," he said, his voice softening. "But there's a better way to do it. There's a way to challenge the system, to bring about change, without resorting to violence and destruction."

The Vandal glared up at him, his eyes still blazing with intensity. "You don't understand, Guardian," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. "You're just a pawn of the system, a tool of the corporations. You're not fighting for justice, you're fighting for the status quo."

The Guardian sighed, his expression a mix of sadness and frustration. He knew that The Vandal was right, that the system was broken, and that change was needed. But he also knew that violence and destruction were not the answers.

As he stood over The Vandal, he made a decision. He would work with the city's authorities to bring about change, to create a system that was fair and just for all. And he would do it without resorting to violence and destruction.

The Vandal, meanwhile, was taken away, his plans foiled once again. But as he was dragged off into the night, he smiled to himself, his eyes gleaming with a fierce intensity.

The battle may have been lost, but the war was far from over.

prompt: You 're an end-game level 50 god in the underworld . A new level 1 player is pestering you by hitting your ankle with a wooden sword .
story: NEDD looked down at the rhythmic sound of wood clanging against your gargantuan cloven hoof . <newline> *sigh* what is the world coming to ? That this semi-naked warrior with nothing but a wooden sword had reached his domain meant the guardians of all the lower levels had failed to prevent this nobody to pass , there was no way he could have actually bested them was there ? <newline> <newline> How had this human reached the feet of the Nether Elemental Daemon of Destruction , Unspoken Shadow King of the Greater Nether Realm and Lord of all the Arcane ? He went by NEDD because his given name was horrendous , but he was still the most powerful warrior bar none ! He stood protecting the gate to his mistress ' layer and none had ever passed him . Few ever reached his gates and those that did normally took one look , bowed before him and backed away to find a less daunting prize . <newline> <newline> The challenger took a final swing and his wooden sword staggered against his hoof . There was a mark on the armour plaiting but it looked like bits of wood ground against the chitinous plate , rather than any damage to his person . The challenger backed off and dropped the broken handle on the stone floor , littering was not something he liked but the maintenance goblins would be round later to clean up anyway so it was n't a problem . <newline> <newline> The tiny human shuffled his pouch and withdrew another wooden sword and resumed . <newline> <newline> NEDD sighed and buried his face in his hand . This was growing tiresome . Standing from his basalt throne he paced to the other side of the room , far outpacing what an I enhanced human would be capable of . Once he reached the other side of the hall he turned and true enough the tiny human was only a third of the way to him . <newline> <newline> Deciding to humour the creature he drew drew his blade and sliced the chain holding open the door . He stood at 40m high so when the 100m wide by 50m high door fell it released a tremendous shockwave that knocked the human skidding across the floor . It stood up and looked around for it 's sword . It was gone . <newline> <newline> NEDD paced across the room and hauled open a draw inset to the wall . The door was enchanted so that when it closed it would disarm challengers , anything held in their hands would be teleported to this draw . He picked through the contents and found what he was looking for . He picked up the jewel studded necklace and for humour grabbed the wooden sword . <newline> <newline> He glanced over to where the human stood watching him and threw the sword and necklace so they skidded to within a few meters of the challenger . The human moved to pick up the items and NEDD sat down again on his throne . <newline> <newline> For a daemon NEDD had a particularly nice voice , it was deep and strong and reverberated so that you felt the lower consonants rather than hearing them . `` What brings you to this place mortal ? '' NEDD was technically mortal too but he could pull off the look and did so as his standard greeting to challengers . <newline> <newline> The human spoke but being so far away and so quiet he could not be heard . NEDD cut him off `` Put on the necklace ! You should have crafted one with the sisters of Thaler 's Vale ? '' <newline> <newline> It was a statement left hanging that demanded a response and as he human put on the necklace he received one . <newline> `` Hello , I 'm Peter . '' <newline> <newline> NEDD 's brow furrowed , that was not quite as informing as he hoped . Just being blunt might work better . <newline> <newline> `` How did you get here ? '' <newline> <newline> `` I ran most of the way . '' <newline> <newline> Again not really telling him anything useful . <newline> <newline> `` What ... How ... '' NEDD paused and grumbled to himself before speaking loudly but clearly `` I dislike pointless threats but you may not have realised that I am a guardian of this hall ! I can CRUSH you with almost no effort and will do so without hesitating . How exactly did you make your way past all the previous guardians ? '' <newline> <newline> The human paused `` killed them . '' <newline> <newline> Now that was interesting `` Go on ... '' <newline> <newline> `` I was created by an incredibly powerful Mage . Born under a new moon that coincided with a solar eclipse at midday on the winter solstice . Conceived with no mother . 7 virgin sacrifices fuelled my creation and the blood of a thousand warriors . '' <newline> <newline> NEDD raised an eyebrow , `` and they call you Peter ? '' <newline> <newline> `` Well I had to be called something did n't I ? '' <newline> <newline> `` And they chose Peter ... '' <newline> <newline> `` Why is the name Peter the part you 're questioning here ? '' <newline> <newline> `` I just struggle to see how they 'd go to all that trouble and name you something as banal as Peter . '' <newline> <newline> `` Mhmhehmmm '' The challenger mumbled <newline> <newline> `` What was that ? '' <newline> <newline> `` If you really must know , Peter is not my given name . It was my wizard creator 's name and I took it when I killed him '' <newline> <newline> `` Now that is more believable , now onto the rest of your tale . You do n't look very ... '' Peter looked at him questioningly `` ... threatening . '' <newline> <newline> `` Well I 'm not really , I do n't have super human strength or the gift of otherworldly magic . I 'm clever but not nearly as sharp as a magically enhanced mind . I 'm fairly squishy , I cut easily , I 'm regularly seriously injured by plants and rocks that are just lying about . I have a ludicrously high pain threshold but I 'm really very easy to kill . '' <newline> <newline> `` I 'm sorry , I must have missed something . How do you plan on getting past me ? '' <newline> <newline> `` Well that 's simple '' and with a smile he took his pathetic wooden sword and sliced his own neck open . '' <newline> <newline> `` Oh ... '' that was rather anticlimactic . <newline> <newline> But then Peter stood up `` I 've been killed literally thousands of time getting here , but never permanently . The early guardians took a few attempts to learn how to kill them , some of them just got worn down over time . A few just let me past because they got bored of killing me . If I 'm killed very badly I 'll loose any armour I have which I why I only have a wooden sword but I wo n't ever stop . '' <newline> <newline> `` Oh , that does explain allot . '' <newline> <newline> Peter and NEDD just looked at each other for a while before Peter spoke . `` So what now ? '' <newline> <newline> `` What a question ! '' NEDD leapt to his hooves and swept across the room . In two paces he was at Peter and he swung his feet in an arc . <newline> <newline> Peter died first upon contact with several tones of very solid hoof . He then redirected in the air just long enough to regret starting this , before he smashed into the stone wall and his head exploding . <newline> <newline> `` What now Peter ? What now ? '' <newline> <newline> The human stood , drenched in warm fresh blood . In front of him NEDD burst into flame and drew a pair of swords that probably sighed more than a house each . `` Now I face an opponent worthy of my effort ! '' <newline> <newline> The fire elemental pointed his sword at Peter and the world turned to flame . Before he was roasted for the first of many times Peter thought 'here we go again ' .

prompt: You 're an end-game level 50 god in the underworld . A new level 1 player is pestering you by hitting your ankle with a wooden sword .
story:
I sat upon my throne, carved from the very rock of the underworld, my piercing gaze surveying the realm below. The screams of the damned echoed through the caverns, a constant reminder of my power and dominion. My name was whispered in terror by the mortals who dared to cross my path.

As I brooded, a faint rustling caught my attention. I raised an eyebrow, my eyes narrowing as a tiny figure emerged from the shadows. A level 1 player, clad in tattered armor and wielding a wooden sword, approached me with an air of determination.

The player, oblivious to the fact that I was a god, charged forward with a battle cry. His sword, a pathetic wooden stick, struck my ankle with a dull thud. I winced, not from pain, but from annoyance. How dare this insignificant mortal think they could harm me?

I raised my hand, and a wave of dark energy washed over the player. He stumbled back, his eyes wide with fear, but instead of falling, he simply stumbled and fell to the ground. I sighed, my patience wearing thin.

The player scrambled to his feet, his wooden sword at the ready. He charged forward once more, striking my ankle with a series of feeble blows. I let out a low growl, my annoyance growing.

Why did this mortal insist on bothering me? Did they not know that I was a god, a being of immense power and authority? I raised my hand once more, and a bolt of lightning shot forth, striking the player with incredible force.

But to my surprise, the player simply got up, dusting himself off. He charged forward once more, his wooden sword flashing in the dim light of the underworld. I was taken aback, my curiosity piqued.

This mortal was...different. Most players would have fled in terror, or at the very least, tried to negotiate with me. But not this one. They seemed to be driven by a singular purpose, a determination that bordered on obsession.

I watched, fascinated, as the player struck my ankle with blow after blow. Each strike was feeble, but it was the player's persistence that was truly remarkable. I found myself...amused.

For the first time in eons, I felt a spark of excitement. This mortal was a challenge, a test of my powers and my patience. I decided to indulge them, to see just how far they would push me.

I raised my hand, and the player's wooden sword was imbued with a faint glow. The strikes grew stronger, more confident, and I found myself laughing, a deep, rumbling sound that shook the foundations of the underworld.

The player's eyes widened in surprise, but they did not falter. They struck my ankle with a mighty blow, and I felt a surge of power course through me. I was a god, but this mortal had just become my new favorite plaything.

And so, the game began. I would toy with this player, push them to their limits, and see just how far they would go. The underworld would never be the same again, and I couldn't wait to see what this level 1 player had in store for me.

prompt: There is a lamp that have granted three wishes to hundreds of the people through the history . You are that genie , tell us about the highlights .
story: This one 's a throwback to [ a previous story of mine ] ( https : //www.reddit.com/r/WritingPrompts/comments/27dnnu/wp_a_lonely_teenage_boy_asks_a_genie_to_let_him/ci080ps ) . You do n't have to read it to understand this one , but it might be useful : ) <newline> <newline> -- - <newline> <newline> The Fairy lowered its dead , dull eyes to Onygos . Little known fact : fairies are only joyful and splendorous when they wish to impress mortals . In the Spirit Realm , they do n't bother to turn on their precious magic . <newline> <newline> This particular fairy was holding a tiny clipboard and standing on a stool , putting it on the level of Onygos ' face without the need to flap its wings . <newline> <newline> `` Let me get this straight , '' it spoke in a nasal voice . `` You claim to be a *genie* , yet you are not bound to any lamp to speak of ... have no wish-granting abilities , and- '' the Fairy glanced at Onygos ' wrist `` No narrativial watch . '' <newline> <newline> `` I 'm telling you ! '' Onygos exclaimed desperately . `` I 've been set up . That kid , the boy , he *stole* my watch ! '' Onygos clenched his fists . `` And then he *broke* my lamp , the little brat ! '' <newline> <newline> `` And where is this 'boy ' now ? '' The Fairy smirked , looking around the entrance lobby to the Spirit Realm . <newline> <newline> `` If I knew that I would n't be in this situation , now would I ? '' Onygos said sarcastically . <newline> <newline> The Fairy frowned . `` Alright , maybe you want me to take this up with the Big Guy , then ? '' <newline> <newline> `` No ! '' Onygos paled , all the red draining from his face , leaving his stylized eyebrows all the more distinctive in their mounting panic . <newline> <newline> `` Listen , '' he said , taking off his sunglasses , `` No need to get hasty . I 've got plenty stories about my past , stories only a genie would know ... stories that would blow your mind , ya hear ? Stories are a genie 's business , after all ! '' <newline> <newline> He calmed down a bit , putting his sunglasses back on . The Fairy waited , though it failed to conceal its persistent boredom . <newline> <newline> `` Like my first Wish Master . That was about two thousand years back . This guy , useless as a toothless lion - he had the hippie type down ages before they invented the thing ! But he stumbles upon this lamp of mine - lovely stone volute type , by the way , balm oil - '' <newline> <newline> Onygos had a distant , nostalgic look on him , before he once again realised the situation he was in , `` Anyway , this *carpenter 's son* , ya hear , he tells me his wish is 'World Peace ' . '' <newline> <newline> Onygos gave the Fairy a look that said it all . `` World Peace , I ask you ! Who seriously asks for that ? This was my first Wish Master , remember , so I gently inform him that it 's a bit above my capacities . So he thinks for a while , then goes : 'make me perform miracles ' . '' <newline> <newline> Onygos sighed , rubbing the bridge of his nose . `` So I tell him : 'Jesus , pal , that 's against the rules , it 's wishing for more wishes ' . I 'm getting nervous here on my first job , and I 'm feeling sorry for this kid who 's too nice for his own good , so I make a mistake : 'Tell you what , ' I say , 'I can give you *some* permanent powers , all you got ta do is be *specific* . How about the power to make women fall madly in love with you , eh ? '' <newline> <newline> Onygos suggestively wiggled his eyebrows at the Fairy , but quickly continued the story upon seeing its deepening frown . `` Anyway , get this , he wishes for a bunch of totally useless stuff like 'healing the sick ' , or 'walking on water ' . Me , I 'm freaked out by this point , so I just give the kid what he wants and disappear . '' <newline> <newline> `` You 're telling me your first Wish Master was Jesus , '' the Fairy said dryly , raising one incredulous eyebrow . <newline> <newline> `` Gave me a lot of trouble with the Big Guy , '' Onygos said nervously . `` It was way too much , you see , we had to cover it up , make it seem like the Big Guy intended it . Amyria thought the whole thing was a riot , of course , '' the genie scowled when he remembered his sister 's reaction . `` But it was a mess , really . '' <newline> <newline> The Fairy was writing something down on its little clipboard , unimpressed , and Onygos hesitantly cleared his throat . <newline> <newline> `` They revoked my license , in fact . Did n't get it back until the end of the 18th century . '' <newline> <newline> `` Let me guess , '' the Fairy said dryly . `` You single-handedly caused the French Revolution . '' <newline> <newline> `` Not ... quite , '' Onygos mumbled , frowning . `` Though that does remind me- '' <newline> <newline> `` Oh , '' the Fairy said sardonically , `` *Do* go on . '' <newline> <newline> -- - <newline> <newline> I 'll do another story if I feel like it , and if there is some demand for it : )

prompt: There is a lamp that have granted three wishes to hundreds of the people through the history . You are that genie , tell us about the highlights .
story:
The weight of centuries rests upon my shoulders, a burden I've grown accustomed to over the years. I am the lamp's keeper, the guardian of its secrets, and the wielder of its immense power. For as long as anyone can remember, this lamp has been granting three wishes to those who find it, their desires and dreams manifesting before their very eyes.

I recall the first wish, made by a young pharaoh in ancient Egypt. He wished for the Nile to overflow its banks, bringing fertility to the land and prosperity to his people. The gods smiled upon him, and the Nile did indeed overflow, bringing forth a bounty of crops and livestock. The pharaoh's people rejoiced, and his legacy lived on for generations.

Next, I was summoned by a medieval knight, who wished for the strength and courage to vanquish his enemies and protect the innocent. I granted him the power of a hundred warriors, and he rode into battle, his sword shining with a light that seemed almost divine. The knight's name became synonymous with bravery, and his deeds were told and retold in taverns and castles for centuries.

But perhaps the most memorable wish was made by a young artist, who wished for the ability to create masterpieces that would be remembered for eternity. I granted her the gift of inspiration, and her brushstrokes brought forth works of beauty that captivated the hearts of kings and commoners alike. Her name became a byword for genius, and her art continues to inspire and delight to this day.

As the years passed, I granted wishes for wealth and power, for love and happiness, and for the eradication of suffering and disease. I saw empires rise and fall, and I watched as humanity made progress and stumbled. Through it all, the lamp remained a constant, a reminder of the power of human desire and the boundless potential of the human spirit.

But with great power comes great responsibility, and I have learned to be cautious in my granting of wishes. I have seen the darker side of human nature, the selfishness and greed that can lead to destruction and chaos. I have watched as wishes have been made with ulterior motives, and as the consequences of those wishes have been dire.

Despite these lessons, I remain committed to my duty, granting wishes to those who seek them with a pure heart and a noble intention. For in the end, it is not the wishes themselves that bring happiness, but the journey that leads to them. And it is in the journey that we discover our true potential, and the true meaning of our existence.

As I sit here, surrounded by the whispers of the past, I am reminded of the lamp's power and the weight of its responsibility. I am the keeper of its secrets, and the guardian of its power. And I will continue to grant wishes, one by one, until the lamp's magic is spent, and the world is forever changed.

prompt: After nearly one hundred generations on a colony ship , the ships original mission has become like a religion . Some still believe , while others deny that there ever was a goal .
story: As i stared deeply into the space as i did every morning , while i smashed the snooze on the holo-screen , i thought . Has it been always like this ? <newline> I was born on *Oedipus* a class seven citzen-transport ship , by now my home , and i knew nothing else , but the vastness of emptiness that surrounded the ship . <newline> One thing was clear : it had been like this since *always* . <newline> everything was automated : all those robots , life support systems , and steel covering of the oedipus had always been there . <newline> Or at least i though it was like that . <newline> I never actually never got to know my parents . It was inefficient . Every inhabitant in the oedipus was born and taken away from their parents ; raised with their generational group , and then taken to training . No time for the parents to raise a child , they had to comply with the ships labours , everyone ... And i mean EVERYONE , had a job . <newline> there was no actual time to wonder were you came from when you had to work 18 timeclicks a shift . All shifts the same : rest , work , ingest , rest , work , ingest ... . <newline> <newline> and as a productive member of society , i had a job too . <newline> <newline> I headed down the aisle to the gravi-lift that was intended to take me down to the machinery room where i was intended to do fusion material recycle labor for 9 clicks and maintenance for another 9 . <newline> I entered the chamber , started to hoover , down when suddenly , a voice reverberated inside the transport tube . <newline> `` CITZEN R-89/ty/01 YOU HAVE BEEN SUMMONED TO HIGH COMMAND , REPORT IMMEDIATELY `` <newline> `` As if i had a choice '' i thought rolling my eyes while the gravity shifted taking me in the opposite direction . <newline> <newline> high command was an edgy nice looking olace . Nothing compared with the recycling system plant . So full of vegetation and colour . <newline> A woman greeted me in the entrance , blonde , nice curves <newline> `` welcome R-ty , had nice trip ? I was expecting for you , My name is M-03-1nA . But you can call me Myna for short , i 'm the high commander in cheif , i would like a few words with you '' she said as she made a gesture with her hands asking me to follow her . <newline> `` You may wonder why i asked you up here , but it 's only a routine thi ... '' <newline> The intercaller rang <newline> `` Just a moment '' ... <newline> `` Yeah ... Of course , another one ... Ok , take them to confinement ... Yes ! Quick ! ! '' <newline> Another one ? Another one what ? Something weird is going on , i think i should get out of here . <newline> `` Where was i ? `` she continued `` oh yeah , the reason why i brought you up here was , to ask a few questions : are you familiar with something called , *the mission* ? '' <newline> `` Yeah , some crazy guys down at the plant are always talking about it , they even stop their labour to discuss it . Something about a place called Earth ... They are sort of nuts , you know , like sayin we all came from there and we are going there someday '' <newline> My voice started to cut , making me nervous <newline> `` i never actually got a grasp of it , sorry '' i mustered . <newline> <newline> <newline> `` i see , so they are becoming aware ... `` Myna said in a deep low voice ... <newline> `` Take him away ! `` she yelled , `` this one is useless too , wipe his memory and find those fanatics '' she faced away as two robot assistants walked in heavily . <newline> They grabbed me quickly , i had no time to react ... . <newline> <newline> <newline> <newline> As i stared deeply into the space as i did every morning , while i smashed the snooze on the holo-screen , i thought : Has it been always like this ? <newline>

prompt: After nearly one hundred generations on a colony ship , the ships original mission has become like a religion . Some still believe , while others deny that there ever was a goal .
story:
The dimly lit corridors of the Aurora's Hope echoed with whispers of a long-forgotten past. The colony ship, once a marvel of human ingenuity, had become a vessel of faith for its inhabitants. The original mission, a mere spark of hope in the darkness of space, had been reduced to a mythic tale, a legend that fueled the dreams and doubts of its people.

Aria stood at the edge of the ship's central hub, her eyes scanning the sea of faces before her. Some wore the symbol of the Aurora's Hope emblazoned on their chests, a badge of honor that signified their devotion to the ship's original purpose. Others, like her, wore a simple, silver pin – a token of their skepticism.

As a child, Aria had been taught that the Aurora's Hope was bound for a new world, a paradise of fertile soil and boundless resources. Her parents had spoken of the ship's manifest, a list of the countless families who had set out on this journey, each one driven by a shared dream of a better life. But as she grew older, Aria began to question the stories. Where was this new world? Why had the ship's logs been so cryptic, its transmissions cut off mid-sentence?

The ship's AI, EVE, had long since ceased to function, its systems failing in a catastrophic event that had left the crew and passengers stunned. The ship's logs, once a treasure trove of information, had been reduced to a series of cryptic messages and fragmented data. It was as if the very fabric of reality had been torn apart, leaving behind only whispers of a forgotten past.

Aria's thoughts were interrupted by the soft voice of her friend, Kael. "Aria, come with me," he said, his eyes shining with a mixture of excitement and trepidation. "I've found something."

Together, they made their way to the ship's engineering deck, a labyrinthine maze of pipes and machinery. Kael led her to a hidden compartment, tucked away behind a false wall. Inside, they found a series of ancient logs, the handwriting worn and faded with age.

As they pored over the documents, Aria's doubts began to fade. The truth was not a simple one – the Aurora's Hope had never been bound for a new world. The ship's original mission had been a ruse, a desperate attempt to escape the dying Earth. The crew and passengers had been told of a distant planet, a world of plenty and promise, but it was all a lie.

The realization was both exhilarating and terrifying. Aria felt a sense of freedom, of release, as the weight of the ship's original mission lifted from her shoulders. But she also knew that this newfound knowledge came with a price – the truth was a burden, one that would forever change the way she saw the world and her place in it.

As they emerged from the compartment, Aria caught a glimpse of the ship's symbol, emblazoned on the chest of a fellow passenger. For a moment, she felt a pang of sadness, a sense of loss for the myth that had sustained them for so long. But then she looked at Kael, and saw the same spark of curiosity in his eyes. Together, they knew that they would forge a new path, one that would take them into the unknown, and beyond the boundaries of the Aurora's Hope.

story: `` For the safety and well-being of all local citizens this warning will be broadcast silently . '' <newline> <newline> The text scrolled slowly across the TV set in my living room , and I peered at it , puzzled , from my kitchen . I had n't turned on the TV yet . Hell , I had n't turned it on in weeks . ( Netflix worked better on my laptop , and it was a pain in the ass to plug it into the screen . ) <newline> <newline> “ Do not pay attention to anything that you hear until instructed otherwise . There have been reports of mass auditory hallucinations in your area . We are investigating . As soon as we know more , we promise , you will be informed. ” <newline> <newline> All ... right . So that was not the most encouraging thing to see before the coffee machine had finished working through . <newline> <newline> Even *less* encouraging was the woman 's voice that abruptly came from clock-radio by my bed . The clock radio that *I had n't turned on either . * I could hear incredible stress in her voice , although she was clearly keeping it together . <newline> <newline> “ For the safety and well-being of all local citizens , ” she said crisply , “ This warning will be broadcast audibly . Do not pay attention to anything that you see until instructed otherwise . There have been reports of mass visual hallucinations in your area . We are investigating . As soon as we know more , we promise , you will be informed. ” <newline> <newline> Her voice took on a ragged tone , exhaustion and worry creeping in . “ Do n't drive , for God 's sake . Do n't operate heavy machinery . Please sit down somewhere safe , and close your eyes . Trust us , please , just ... just do n't look around. ” <newline> <newline> New text scrolled across the television screen , error-ridden as if it was being typed with frantic speed . “ Please do nt listen to anything that you heaf . we do not know what is happening at this time . Unplug all speKERS AND RADIOS . IF IN BUILDING WITH PUBLIC ADDRESS SYSTEM , LEAVE BUILDING IN ORDERLY FASHION . Do not listen to voices . Do not close your eyes . prompt: Your T.V . suddenly turns on by itself mid-lunch and a message from the local weather warning system , normally accompanied with a loud alarm but oddly silent this time around , reads `` For the safety and well-being of all local citizens this warning will be broadcasted silently ... ''
story:
I was mid-chew, savoring the flavors of my sandwich, when my TV suddenly sprang to life. I was taken aback, my eyes widening in surprise as the screen flickered on, displaying the familiar logo of our local weather station. But something was off. The usual loud, piercing alarm that accompanied the weather warnings was eerily absent. Instead, a soft, melodic voice spoke, its tone measured and calm.

"For the safety and well-being of all local citizens, this warning will be broadcasted silently today," the voice read from the screen.

I felt a shiver run down my spine as I set my sandwich down, my mind racing with questions. What was going on? Why was the weather warning being broadcasted silently? I glanced around the room, half-expecting to see some sort of emergency response team or government official standing in the corner, but I was alone.

I got up from the couch and walked over to the TV, my eyes fixed on the screen. The weather map displayed a typical summer day, with clear skies and warm temperatures. But the lack of the usual alarm was jarring, and I couldn't shake the feeling that something was off.

I decided to check the news, hoping to find some explanation for the strange broadcast. But as I scrolled through the channels, I realized that every station was showing the same message. It was as if the entire city was under some sort of collective spell, with everyone watching the same silent weather warning.

I felt a sense of unease creeping over me. What was happening? Was this some kind of prank or a genuine emergency? I tried to call my friends and family, but my phone was dead, and the internet was down.

As the minutes ticked by, I grew more and more anxious. The silence was oppressive, and I couldn't shake the feeling that something was lurking just beneath the surface, waiting to pounce.

And then, just as suddenly as it had started, everything went back to normal. The TV flickered off, and the room was silent once more. I was left standing there, feeling shaken and confused, wondering what had just happened.

As I sat back down on the couch, I couldn't help but wonder if I had really seen what I thought I had. Had it all been some kind of bizarre dream, or was there something more sinister at play? I shook my head, trying to clear the cobwebs. Whatever it was, I knew one thing for sure: I would never look at my TV the same way again.

The rest of my lunch was a blur, my mind still reeling from the strange events of the morning. I finished my sandwich in silence, my eyes fixed on the TV, half-expecting it to spring back to life at any moment. But it remained still, a silent witness to the strange and inexplicable events that had unfolded just hours before.
